title: Pound pops as UK and EU reach new Brexit deal
text:
The pound spiked against the dollar and euro on Thursday after the UK and EU agreed a new deal on Brexit.

UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson said in a Tweet at 10.35am on Thursday: “We’ve got a great new deal that takes back control — now Parliament should get Brexit done on Saturday so we can move on to other priorities like the cost of living, the NHS, violent crime and our environment.”

European Council Jean-Claude Juncker also confirmed the deal on Twitter, calling it a “fair and balanced agreement” and urging European leaders to endorse it.

Michel Barnier, the EU’s chief Brexit negotiator, said during a press conference in Brussels: “This text should provide legal certainty in every area where Brexit, like any separation, creates uncertainty.”

He said citizens were the EU’s “priority” in negotiations and said there was “certainty” for citizen’s rights.

Sterling rose 0.9% against the dollar to $1.2935 (GBPUSD=X) and 0.4% against the euro to €1.1624 (GBPEUR=X).

The pound spiked against the dollar. Photo: Yahoo Finance UK More

The deal comes after a week of intense and detailed negotiations between the two sides. It will be presented to European leaders at a two-day summit in Brussels that begins on Thursday.

READ MORE: pound set for biggest rising streak in more than three decades

However, even if it is approved by European leaders, the deal faces a difficult path to ratification. The deal must be approved by the UK’s parliament, which rejected former Prime Minister Theresa May’s withdrawal deal three times.

The pound was under pressure earlier Thursday after Northern Ireland’s Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) rejected a draft text of the deal.

Support from the DUP is crucial for getting any deal through parliament given the ruling Conservative Party’s lack of majority in the House of Commons. The DUP said they stood behind their earlier statement following the publication of the draft deal.

🇪🇺🤝🇬🇧 Where there is a will, there is a #deal - we have one! It’s a fair and balanced agreement for the EU and the UK and it is testament to our commitment to find solutions. I recommend that #EUCO endorses this deal. pic.twitter.com/7AfKyCZ6k9 — Jean-Claude Juncker (@JunckerEU) October 17, 2019

Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn also criticised the deal, saying in a statement: “It seems the Prime Minister has negotiated an even worse deal than Theresa May’s, which was overwhelmingly rejected.”

Jo Swinson, the leader of the Liberal Democrats, the fourth biggest party in the House of Commons, said the deal "would be bad for our economy, bad for our public services, and bad for our environment."

"When this deal comes to Parliament we will use every possible opportunity to give the public a People's Vote on the Brexit deal that includes the option to remain in the European Union," Swinson said in a statement.

Markets reaction

The DUP’s rejection and the parliamentary arithmetic kept a lid on sterling. Analysts had said that a deal between the EU and UK could see the pound rise as high as $1.35.

“If [Boris Johnson] manages to get it through parliament, we should see a wave of ‘risk-on’ trades coming into UK market,” Artur Baluszynski, head of research at investment manager Henderson Rowe, said.

“However, let us wait and see all the details and then let the markets decide how likely it is for the UK parliament to accept it. For now, expect some positive momentum in sterling and domestically focused asset classes.”

The FTSE 250 index (^FTMC), which is weighted towards UK-facing businesses, was up 1% shortly after the deal was announced. The index had been down 0.5% in earlier trade.

The European Commission has published the full details of Boris Johnson's deal. You can find the revised Withdrawal Agreement here.

What happens next?

MPs will hold an extraordinary sitting of Parliament on Saturday to vote on the deal if it is approved by EU leaders.
